bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, December 30, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests permission to examine the files that contain the letters and telegrams between the Surgeon General's office and Walter Reed, dated 1900 and 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, December 30, 1941
div1.opener:
December 30, 1941
Mr. R. H. Brooke, Chief Clerk
War Department
Office of the Surgeon General
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Brooke:
div1.p:
I have had some correspondence with you (your file S G O 201 - Hench, P.S.)
in which you kindly promised that when I come to Washington in January I might see
the files which contain the letters and telegrams between the Surgeon General's
office and Walter Reed and his colleagues in Havana, Cuba, dated 1900 and 1901.
Some months ago you said these were in the quartermaster's warehouse at Myer,
Virginia but that when I came in January you would be able to have them available
for me. I wrote a few days ago asking for confirmation of this but have not heard.

I have a date with Colonel Hillman of the Surgeon General's office on or
about January 13 and expect to spend two or three days in Washington. Could you
write me at your earliest convenience where I shall meet you and whether it would
be possible to see this material? The duration of my Washington stay depends
largely on my ability to see these records and I am anxious to make my final plans
as I am leaving for New York on January 8.

If war-time restrictions have made it necessary for you to investigate
my request, may I state that my identity and purpose are well known to ex-Surgeon
General Merritt Ireland and Brigadier General (retired) Jefferson R. Kean, both
of Washington, D. C.
I am enclosing a stamped envelope for your reply.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
